In addition, two literary instances of the name Hermanubis are mentioned in the autobiography of Gregory of Nazianzus, known as De vita sua, in the context of Maximus the Cynic's attempt to replace him as bishop of Constantinople in 380 AD.

summarise this: White 1996: 73–75)Paul Gallay suggests that the names in 838–839 are fictional and part of the satire: an opportunity to associate the Egyptians, and implicitly the Egyptian church, with their pagan past and its odious animal worship.[25] At any rate, most of the names, Ϲτιππᾶϲ and Ῥόδων excepted, are characteristically Egyptian.[26] The occurrence of Ἄνουβιϲ near Ἑρμάνουβιϲ suggests the near equivalence of the names. The adjective κυνώδειϲ in 840, however, need not imply that Hermanubis refers to the canine-headed god, since it could have been triggered only by the name Ἄνουβιϲ (πιθηκόμορφοι, at least, does not correlate with any of the theophoric names cited).

In Paul Gallay's perspective, names mentioned in Gregory of Nazianzus' autobiography are fictional and satirically link Egyptians and the Egyptian church to their pagan past and animal worship. Most of these names, except for Ϲτιππᾶϲ and Ῥόδων, are characteristically Egyptian. The occurrence of Ἄνουβιϲ near Ἑρμάνουβιϲ suggests their near equivalence. However, the adjective κυνώδειϲ in the text doesn't necessarily imply that Hermanubis refers to the canine-headed god, as it could have been triggered only by the name Ἄνουβιϲ, with no direct correlation to the mentioned theophoric names.

summarise this: The other literary instance similarly exploits the name Hermanubis for satiric effect. This is a curious, though poorly executed, anonymous poem in the Greek Anthology (AP XI 360), a diatribe against some strategos:

Another literary instance that utilizes the name Hermanubis for satirical purposes is a poorly executed, anonymous poem found in the Greek Anthology (AP XI 360). The poem serves as a diatribe against a strategos.

summarise this: Now the strategos Hermanoubes has turned into a dog, having seized two fraternal Hermeses, stealers of treasures, bound with rope, cold daemons of Tartarus before their time. I don't know a place that betrays character; but I say character betrays the place.

In the poem, the strategos Hermanoubes has transformed into a dog, capturing two thieving Hermeses and tying them with a rope, as if they were cold spirits of Tartarus before their time. The poem suggests that character betrays the place, rather than the place betraying character.

summarise this: The form Ἑρμανούβηϲ is not attested in documents. There is likewise no instance of Ἀνούβηϲ (but cf. the Copticized Πανούβηϲ in P.Erl. I 108.ii.50 [Theb.; IV]). It is attractive, therefore, to emend Ἑρμανούβηϲ to Ἑρμάνουβιϲ (the final syllable of the name, being in anceps position, could be either short or long). The implied context of the poem is obscure. There is some hesitation among translators whether Ἑρμανούβηϲ is the subject ("the general H. turned into a dog" [Budé]) or predicate ("the general [unnamed] turned into the dog H." [Loeb]) of ἐγένετο. But surely the satire would be more biting if the general was actually named Hermanoubes/Hermanubis: the poet then would be playing on the associations of his name with Anubis the dog on the one hand (κύων) and Hermes the thief on the other (Ἑρμᾶϲ ... ἀϲημοκλέπταϲ). Whether κύων is a general insult or connotes the protective duties of the strategos is unclear, and so is the nature of the implied relationship between the strategos and the two thievish Hermeses.

The name form Ἑρμανούβηϲ is not found in documents, and there is no instance of Ἀνούβηϲ. It is suggested to emend Ἑρμανούβηϲ to Ἑρμάνουβιϲ. The context of the poem is unclear, with some ambiguity on whether Ἑρμανούβηϲ is the subject or predicate of the phrase. The satire could be more effective if the general was actually named Hermanoubes/Hermanubis, making associations with Anubis the dog and Hermes the thief. It is unclear whether the term "κύων" is a general insult or refers to the protective duties of the strategos, as well as the exact relationship between the strategos and the two thieving Hermeses.

summarise this: Notes See Benaissa 2009. Although it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in the earlier period. The most obvious is the god Ἑρμαφρόδιτοϲ (see Ajootian 1990), attested from the fourth century BC onwards, but his name implies the paradoxical union of two different gods (Hermes and Aphrodite) rather than an assimilation in the manner of Hermanubis. A more apt parallel is provided by Ζηνοποϲειδῶν, an epiclesis of the Carian god Zeus Osogoa, who received the additional determination "Poseidon" as a result of his representation with features such as the trident (see Blümel 1987, 128). In Egyptian religion, the tendency to unite the names of two gods was long established and is well known (cf. Leclant 1975). A comparable form to Hermanubis from the Roman period is Ἡλιοϲέραπιϲ, which is not attested as a personal name (pace Hopfner 1946, 45). Schwartz 1947 also postulates a syncretic funerary god Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, but this is based purely on the iconographical evidence of some seals, without any support from textual sources (the personal name Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, two instances of which have emerged since Schwartz's thesis, could be simply an example of a polytheophoric name and need not imply the recognition of an actual god of that name). The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are collected by Grenier 1977, 53–59, 95–98. Bernand, Inscriptions métriques n. 73 (Abydos; I–II) = GVI 1090, should also be added, as the Κυλλήνιοϲ Ἑρμῆϲ (9) leading the deceased to serve Osiris of Abydos is implicitly conflated with Anubis (see Dunand 1975, 158). Kákosy 1990, 145 points to some pre-Ptolemaic Egyptian statuettes, in which the feet or teeth of Thoth are modeled as jackal heads, as evidence that the later rapprochement of Anubis and Hermes was based on the earlier assimilation of Thoth to Anubis; but although Thoth and Anubis were closely associated in funerary contexts, I am not persuaded that these statuettes "wollten sicher den synkretischen Gott Thoth-Anubis darstellen" or that they are relevant to the question of the origin of the Graeco-Roman Hermanubis. See Leclant 1981, 871, and the references in Grenier 1977, 137–138. In the amulet published in Bonner 1950, n. 36 (Plate II) = LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 19, Anubis is described as holding in his right hand "a tall scepter resembling a Roman military standard, with palm leaves at top, and two garlands, the lower with ties" (Bonner 1950, 259). But this looks to me like a version of the kerykeion-cum-palm known from a number of coins of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis; see Grenier 1990, 265, and cf. the coins under 8(a). Whether the appellation "Hermanubis" was given to the canine-headed Anubis with Hermetic features is uncertain; Apuleius, Met. XI 11, refers to the god attolens canis cernices arduas and laena caduceum gerens simply as "Anubis." LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 13, found in Carthage or Cherchel, is the only representation for which an Alexandrian origin has been postulated, but on no firm basis (see Picard 1956, 176–179, who assigns to it an Alexandrian provenance and a date in the third century BC on the basis of the floral decoration). See Grenier 1990. Cf. Leclant 1981, 873. On "direct theonymy" see Parker 2000, 57–8, with further bibliography. For the accentuation Ἑρμάνουβιϲ rather than Ἑρμανοῦβιϲ (Preisigke and some editors), see Clarysse 1997, 180. While the letter was found in the Fayum, the sender is clearly writing from Alexandria; cf. Bagnall and Cribiore 2006, 389–390. For some observations on the marking of gender in Greek personal names, see Davies 2000, 20–21. Cf. Gignac, Grammar, II 55–57; Mayser, Grammatik, I.2 22–23. For masculine names in -ιϲ, -ιδοϲ/-ιοϲ and feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ, see Pape-Benseler, Wörterbuch der griechischen Eigennamen3, xviii-xix. See e.g. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 33–34; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 34–35. See e.g. the "index des suffixes" in Masson 1990, II 632–633 s.v. -ᾶϲ ("suffixe d'hypocoristique et de sobriquet masculin").

Names based on Hermanubis, such as Ἑρμανούβηϲ, were not commonly attested in literature. The poem involving the strategos exploits the name Hermanubis for satirical effect. Anubis was often associated with Hermes in Graeco-Roman contexts, but few instances of direct combinations have been found in documents. The origin of the assimilation between Anubis and Hermes remains uncertain; however, they were closely related in the context of funerary practices. "Direct theonymy", or the use of unaltered divine names for humans, became widespread during the Roman period.

summarise this: The personal name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ and related forms are usually subsumed under the category of "polytheophoric" names characteristic of Roman Egypt. These are names that combine the names of two deities, such as Ἡρακλαπόλλων or Ἑρμαντίνοοϲ. They are attested solely in the Roman period, especially between the second and the fourth centuries, and were predominantly popular among males of the middle and upper classes in certain metropoleis like Hermopolis.[1] The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, however, though formally combining two divine names, is somewhat special: unlike other polytheophoric names, it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested in Roman Egypt. In other words, it is the name of the god himself that is a "polytheophoric" formation, and this has some consequences on how the personal names based on this deity are formed. Before discussing these names, it is appropriate first to give a brief summary of our state of knowledge about Hermanubis. After reviewing the name forms based on this deity, the onomastic evidence will be related and compared to his iconographical and documentary attestations.

The name "Hermanubis" is a type of "polytheophoric" name found in Roman Egypt, which combines the names of two deities. While such names were popular among middle and upper-class males in cities like Hermopolis, Hermanubis is special because it refers to a specific deity. The article will explore the different name forms based on this deity and compare them to evidence in iconography and documents.

summarise this: The personal name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ and related forms are usually subsumed under the category of "polytheophoric" names characteristic of Roman Egypt. These are names that combine the names of two deities, such as Ἡρακλαπόλλων or Ἑρμαντίνοοϲ. They are attested solely in the Roman period, especially between the second and the fourth centuries, and were predominantly popular among males of the middle and upper classes in certain metropoleis like Hermopolis.[1] The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, however, though formally combining two divine names, is somewhat special: unlike other polytheophoric names, it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested in Roman Egypt. In other words, it is the name of the god himself that is a "polytheophoric" formation, and this has some consequences on how the personal names based on this deity are formed. Before discussing these names, it is appropriate first to give a brief summary of our state of knowledge about Hermanubis. After reviewing the name forms based on this deity, the onomastic evidence will be related and compared to his iconographical and documentary attestations.

The name "Hermanubis" is a type of "polytheophoric" name that combines the names of two deities, but it refers to a specific god independently attested in Roman Egypt. The name was popular among males of the middle and upper classes in certain cities. The article intends to discuss the formation of personal names based on this deity by reviewing the name forms, onomastic evidence and comparing them to the deity's iconographical and documentary attestations.

summarise this: The divine name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period.[2] Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect (De Is. et Os. 375e), while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as ϲύνθετοϲ, "composite," and μιξέλλην, "half-Greek" (De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18.1–2 Bidez). The name has been restored in a second-century BC dedicatory inscription from Delos (ID 2156.2 [Ἑρ]μανού[βιδι νικ]ηφόρωι), which would be its earliest attestation, but otherwise it appears in three inscriptions of the Roman period, two from Egypt and one from Thessalonike (see below). It is clear that the name is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in a number of literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources.[3] Although Hermes was traditionally equated with the Egyptian Thoth, his function as psychopompos encouraged his association with Anubis given the latter's comparable funerary role in Egyptian religion as embalmer and guardian of the dead and as leader of the deceased to the tribunal of Osiris. This assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, such as the distinctive staff known as the kerykeion or winged sandals.[4] As far as I know, none of these representations whose provenance is known was found in Egypt, though this may be due to mere chance.[5] But in Roman Alexandria there emerges a new iconographical type, well represented in coins and sculpture, in which a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis, in addition to wearing the calathos headdress.[6] It is this type that art historians have traditionally labeled "Hermanubis." In making this identification, they have been encouraged by Porphyry's statement about the god's "composite" and "half-Hellenic" character. However, it is important to stress that the reference to the fully anthropomorphic type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and that not a single of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.[7] I will return to this question at the end of the paper in light of the onomastic evidence.

The name "Hermanubis" is known from a few literary sources and inscriptions of the Roman period, but its assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes is well attested in various sources. The assimilation resulted in various representations of Anubis with attributes of Hermes. In Roman Alexandria, a new iconographical type emerged, which art historians have traditionally labeled "Hermanubis," but none of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such. The article aims to provide more insights into the onomastic evidence related to the formation of personal names based on this deity.

summarise this: 	The personal name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ and related forms are usually subsumed under the category of "polytheophoric" names characteristic of Roman Egypt. These are names that combine the names of two deities, such as Ἡρακλαπόλλων or Ἑρμαντίνοοϲ. They are attested solely in the Roman period, especially between the second and the fourth centuries, and were predominantly popular among males of the middle and upper classes in certain metropoleis like Hermopolis.[1] The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, however, though formally combining two divine names, is somewhat special: unlike other polytheophoric names, it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested in Roman Egypt. In other words, it is the name of the god himself that is a "polytheophoric" formation, and this has some consequences on how the personal names based on this deity are formed. Before discussing these names, it is appropriate first to give a brief summary of our state of knowledge about Hermanubis. After reviewing the name forms based on this deity, the onomastic evidence will be related and compared to his iconographical and documentary attestations.

The name "Hermanubis" is a polytheophoric name, combining two deity names, which was popular in Roman Egypt between the second and fourth centuries. However, Hermanubis is unique in that it refers to a specific god that was independently attested in Roman Egypt, unlike other polytheophoric names. The article discusses the state of knowledge about Hermanubis and examines the onomastic evidence relating to the deity.

summarise this: 	The divine name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period.[2] Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect (De Is. et Os. 375e), while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as ϲύνθετοϲ, "composite," and μιξέλλην, "half-Greek" (De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18.1–2 Bidez). The name has been restored in a second-century BC dedicatory inscription from Delos (ID 2156.2 [Ἑρ]μανού[βιδι νικ]ηφόρωι), which would be its earliest attestation, but otherwise it appears in three inscriptions of the Roman period, two from Egypt and one from Thessalonike (see below). It is clear that the name is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in a number of literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources.[3] Although Hermes was traditionally equated with the Egyptian Thoth, his function as psychopompos encouraged his association with Anubis given the latter's comparable funerary role in Egyptian religion as embalmer and guardian of the dead and as leader of the deceased to the tribunal of Osiris. This assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, such as the distinctive staff known as the kerykeion or winged sandals.[4] As far as I know, none of these representations whose provenance is known was found in Egypt, though this may be due to mere chance.[5] But in Roman Alexandria there emerges a new iconographical type, well represented in coins and sculpture, in which a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis, in addition to wearing the calathos headdress.[6] It is this type that art historians have traditionally labeled "Hermanubis." In making this identification, they have been encouraged by Porphyry's statement about the god's "composite" and "half-Hellenic" character. However, it is important to stress that the reference to the fully anthropomorphic type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and that not a single of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.[7] I will return to this question at the end of the paper in light of the onomastic evidence.

The name "Hermanubis" is found in a few Roman period sources, where it is recognized as a combination of the Greek god Hermes and the Egyptian god Anubis. Plutarch identified Hermanubis as Anubis in his underworldly aspect, while Porphyry referred to Hermanubis as "composite" and "half-Greek." This assimilation of the two gods resulted in many representations of a canine-headed Anubis with Hermes' attributes, and in Alexandria, a fully anthropomorphic young god flanked by a dog and holding the same attributes as Anubis emerged. However, the label "Hermanubis" for this type is only a hypothetical convention as no legend or inscription identifies it as such.

summarise this: 	There are three forms of the personal name based on Hermanubis in papyri and inscriptions from Egypt, in addition to two "proper" polytheophoric names. (In four instances [1, 5, 17, 21] the ending of the name is abbreviated or not preserved.) The form Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, attested six times (2, 9, 11, 13, 14, 15), simply replicates the god's name without further ado, through the phenomenon of "direct theonymy" (the giving to humans of unaltered divine names) that became widespread in the Roman period.[8] In an odd instance (9) the form Ἑρμανουβιϲ in the nominative is borne by a woman, an Alexandrian nurse (ἡ τροφόϲ).[9] It is highly unusual for female theophoric names to be unmarked for gender in this way.[10] I suspect that because the element -ανουβιϲ in Ἑρμάνουβιϲ was often declined with a dental declension in -ιδ-, it might have been conflated with the similar declension of Greek feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ.[11] If this is correct, it may be preferable to read the nurse's name as an oxytone (Ἑρμανουβίϲ). There are two further forms based on the god Hermanubis: Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (six instances: 3, 4, 7, 8, 12, 20) and Ἑρμανουβίων (four instances: 3, 6, 18, 19). -ᾶϲ and -ίων were, in fact, the commonest Greek suffixes for personal names based on the Egyptian god Ἄνουβιϲ.[12] It is interesting that in a business letter (3) the two forms Ἑρμανουβίων (l.38) and Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (l.41) are used interchangeably to designate the same individual. In this case, Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ is probably a hypocoristic of Ἑρμανουβίων, since the suffix -ᾶϲ often served this purpose.[13]

There are three forms of the personal name based on Hermanubis found in papyri and inscriptions from Egypt, in addition to two "proper" polytheophoric names. The form Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, attested six times, simply replicates the god's name without change. In an unusual case, a woman's name is also in this form. Two other forms based on the god are Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ and Ἑρμανουβίων, with the latter being used interchangeably with the former in one instance. The suffix -ᾶϲ is often used as a hypocoristic of Ἑρμανουβίων.

summarise this: 	These forms of the name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ with modified suffixes already separate names based on Hermanubis from other polytheophoric names, which usually simply join two divine names without modifying the original suffix.[14] Indeed, because Hermanubis was conceptualized as a single god, it is not surprising to find personal names such as Ἑρμανοβάμμων (16) and Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ (10), in which the name of Hermanubis is joined to that of other gods in the characteristic pattern of polytheophoric names. It is misleading to analyze these names as triple theophoric names, for they imply the juxtaposition of only two gods, Hermanubis and Ammon in one, and Hermanubis and Heracles in the other.[15] In this respect, they are not exceptions to the rule that polytheophoric names combine no more than two deities.

The modified suffixes in the forms of the name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ distinguish them from other polytheophoric names, which usually only join two divine names without modifying the suffix. Personal names like Ἑρμανοβάμμων and Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ join Hermanubis with other gods, but they are not triple theophoric names and only imply the juxtaposition of two gods. Therefore, they still follow the rule that polytheophoric names combine only two deities.

summarise this: 	The near majority of the names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri of the second and third centuries AD. Possibly the earliest example is on an ostracon dated to AD 94 (1), but the name there is abbreviated and Ἑρμανο(υβίου) is Wilcken's resolution.[16] Otherwise, the next attestations are from the second quarter of the second century. There are overall eight instances from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. One instance is from an inscription dated broadly to the "imperial period." The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century. What is notable about this chronological distribution is that it corresponds neatly to that of the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known conventionally as "Hermanubis." For example, the great number of Alexandrian coins that show a representation of this type on the reverse range from the reign of Trajan (or possibly as early as Domitian) to the Tetrarchic period. Likewise, the statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs of this god have all been assigned to the second or third century AD.[17]

Most names based on Hermanubis are found in papyri from the second and third centuries AD, with one of the earliest examples being on an ostracon dated to AD 94. The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century. This chronological distribution matches the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known as "Hermanubis," with coin representations ranging from the reign of Trajan to the Tetrarchic period and statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs being assigned to the second or third century AD.

summarise this: 	Geographically, names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but it is important to separate, where possible, the provenance of the papyrus from that of the individuals named therein. When this is done, most of the individuals bearing Hermanubis names for whom we can establish an origin turn out to be Alexandrian or Cynopolite (three instances each). This concentration again coincides with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. Thus, in the precinct of the Alexandrian Serapeum an inscription of uncertain date was found (SB I 3482) dedicated to "Hermanubis, great god, who listens to prayers and grants favours" (Ἑρμανούβιδι θεῶι μεγάλωι | ἐπηκόωι καὶ εὐχαρίϲτωι).[18] Not far from this dedication a statuette of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" was discovered.[19] It is in a suburb of Alexandria, in the sanctuary of Ras el-Soda, that the most famous statue of "Hermanubis" was found (LIMC n. 14). One of the Alexandrian coins representing the god shows him standing inside a temple (LIMC nos. 5a, b), which suggests the existence of such an edifice in the city, probably in the Serapeum precinct given the provenance of the just-mentioned dedication and statuette from there and the frequent iconographical associations between "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in Alexandrian coins.[20] Alexandria, then, clearly emerges as the cult center and probably the birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, which is consonant with the three Alexandrians bearing his name (5, 6, 9).[21] For the Cynopolite nome, the chief centre of the Egyptian god Anubis, the onomastic evidence is more suggestive than the archaeological and the iconographical. Among the three individuals with a name based on Hermanubis (11, 15, 16), there stands out the father of an underage priest of "Anubis, Leto and associated gods" in the Cynopolite village of Laura (15). Since priesthood was usually hereditary, the father Hermanubis was probably himself a priest of these gods. This onomastic connection of Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome also has an echo in the iconography: one or two Alexandrian coins personify the Cynopolite nome with a representation of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" on their reverse (LIMC nos. 3, 22).

Names based on Hermanubis are found in papyri from various areas of Egypt, with most individuals bearing these names turning out to be Alexandrian or Cynopolite. This concentration aligns with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. Alexandria emerges as the cult center and probable birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, which is consistent with the three Alexandrians bearing his name. Cynopolite, the chief center of the Egyptian god Anubis, is associated with Hermanubis through the onomastic connection of a father of an underage priest of Anubis, Leto and associated gods. This connection also has an echo in the iconography of one or two Alexandrian coins personifying the Cynopolite nome with a representation of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" on their reverse.

summarise this: 	Three conclusions flow from this onomastic survey. First, names based on Hermanubis stand somewhat apart from other polytheophoric names common in the same period in Roman Egypt because, unlike the latter, they refer to a specific and independently attested god: a hybrid-named Hellenized version of Anubis. This is visible in the "onomastic behaviour" of Hermanubis names, such as their receptivity to various suffixes and their composition with names of other gods in "proper" polytheophoric formations. Second, the precise chronological and geographical overlap between the onomastic evidence and the representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god known conventionally as "Hermanubis" supports art historians' designation of the latter as "Hermanubis" (for which there is otherwise no positive support; see above). Finally, the connection of Hermanubis with Cynopolis evidenced by some of the personal names, and especially the connection with a priest of Anubis, suggests that Hermanubis continued to be closely associated with the traditional Anubis. It may not be warranted, therefore, to separate too forcefully, in the manner of Jean-Claude Grenier (1990: 265, 268), the more traditional funerary Anubis of the Isiac cult from a more "universalizing" Hermanubis.[22]

Three conclusions can be drawn from this onomastic survey. First, names based on Hermanubis are different from other polytheophoric names because they refer to a specific and independently attested god. Second, the chronological and geographical overlap between the onomastic evidence and the representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god supports the designation of the latter as "Hermanubis." Finally, the connection of Hermanubis with Cynopolis suggests that Hermanubis continued to be associated with the traditional Anubis, and separating the two may not be justified.

summarise this: 	I conclude by noting that a name based on Hermanubis is attested once outside Egypt in an inscription from Dion in Macedonia dated to the imperial period (22). The form of the name there is Ἑρμα-νούβιοϲ, which is not known from Egypt. The name is probably to be related to the cult of Hermanubis attested by a third-century dedication in Thessalonike (across the Thermaic golf from Dion), which was set up by a cultic association of Hermanubis on behalf of certain individuals. This document and the personal name, along with a statue of the god from the Sarapeum of Carthage (LIMC n. 15), suggest that the cult of Hermanubis enjoyed some popularity outside its original home in the Roman period.[23]

conversation.content: summarise this: 	The near majority of the names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri of the second and third centuries AD. Possibly the earliest example is on an ostracon dated to AD 94 (1), but the name there is abbreviated and Ἑρμανο(υβίου) is Wilcken's resolution.[16] Otherwise, the next attestations are from the second quarter of the second century. There are overall eight instances from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. One instance is from an inscription dated broadly to the "imperial period." The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century. What is notable about this chronological distribution is that it corresponds neatly to that of the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known conventionally as "Hermanubis." For example, the great number of Alexandrian coins that show a representation of this type on the reverse range from the reign of Trajan (or possibly as early as Domitian) to the Tetrarchic period. Likewise, the statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs of this god have all been assigned to the second or third century AD.[17]

conversation.content: summarise this: 	The ending -άμμων was attached to the names of most deities that appear in theophoric names (see Dunand 1963), so that its union with Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is unlikely to have a specific significance. One may adduce some numismatic representations in which "Hermanubis" is shown with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon; see LIMC V s.v. Hermanubis nos. 10a, b. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more intriguing and difficult to account for. If the papyrus is from the Heracleopolite nome as the ed. princ. suggests with a question mark (no internal evidence confirms this), the name may simply juxtapose the chief god of the nome (Heracles = Egyptian Harsenuphis) with Hermanubis, without necessarily implying an affinity between the two. For what it is worth, a coin from the reign of Antoninus Pius (Milne, Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins 1678 [Plate II]) shows jugate busts of Heracles and "Hermanubis." For a representation of the dog-headed Anubis with a club, see LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 35. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ does not actually occur in Egyptian documents, though Ἀνούβιοϲ is occasionally attested. The Macedonian inscription discussed below (22) is the only instance of the form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ. See Grenier 1990. On this inscription see Fraser 1972, II 413–414 n. 576. For another inscription from Egypt mentioning Hermanubis, see SB I 238. Fraser 1972, I 269. It is not clear to me to which of the statuettes in LIMC this corresponds (n. 21?). On the associations of "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in iconography, see Grenier 1990, 268. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis attested in 13 (and possibly 14) may also originate from Alexandria. Cf. Plut., De Is. et Os. 375e: Ἄνουβιϲ ... ὅτε καὶ Ἑρμάνουβιϲ ὀνομάζεται, τὸ μὲν ὡϲ τοῖϲ ἄνω τὸ δ᾿ ὡϲ τοῖϲ κάτω προϲήκων. Addendum, January 2010: The female name Ἑρμανουβίαινα (referring to an ἀϲτή, i.e. a citizen of Alexandria or one of the three Greek cities of Egypt) is now attested in P.Mich. inv. 1960.3 (17 March 291), published by L.H. Blumell, ZPE 165 (2008) 186–190. I have not been able to consult D. Stefanovic, "The Iconography of Hermanubis," in H. Györy (ed.), Aegyptus et Pannonia III. Acta Symposii anno 2004 (Budapest 2006) 271–276. For a recent text and translation of this work, see Lukinovich and Martingay 1997. Ch. Jungck's edition with commentary (Diss. Basel 1974) was not available to me.

The suffix -άμμων was commonly added to the names of deities in theophoric names, so the addition of this suffix to Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is not significant. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more difficult to explain, but it may simply be a combination of the chief god of a region (Heracles) with Hermanubis. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ is not found in Egyptian documents, but has been found in a Macedonian inscription. "Hermanubis" is often associated with Sarapis in iconography. conversation.content: summarise this: These forms of the name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ with modified suffixes already separate names based on Hermanubis from other polytheophoric names, which usually simply join two divine names without modifying the original suffix.[14] Indeed, because Hermanubis was conceptualized as a single god, it is not surprising to find personal names such as Ἑρμανοβάμμων (16) and Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ (10), in which the name of Hermanubis is joined to that of other gods in the characteristic pattern of polytheophoric names. It is misleading to analyze these names as triple theophoric names, for they imply the juxtaposition of only two gods, Hermanubis and Ammon in one, and Hermanubis and Heracles in the other.[15] In this respect, they are not exceptions to the rule that polytheophoric names combine no more than two deities.

The modified forms of the name Hermanubis are used to distinguish it from other polytheophoric names, which typically just join two divine names without modifying the suffix. Hermanubis was seen as a single god, so it is common to find personal names combining it with other gods. These names should not be considered triple theophoric names because they only consist of two gods, Hermanubis and another deity. Overall, polytheophoric names only combine two deities, making these names not exceptions to the rule.

Hermánoubis is associated with Sarapis in iconography, and a female name "Ἑρμανουβίαινα" referring to a citizen of Alexandria or a Greek city in Egypt, is now attested in P.Mich. inv. 1960.3 (17 March 291).

conversation.content: summarise this: These forms of the name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ with modified suffixes already separate names based on Hermanubis from other polytheophoric names, which usually simply join two divine names without modifying the original suffix.[14] Indeed, because Hermanubis was conceptualized as a single god, it is not surprising to find personal names such as Ἑρμανοβάμμων (16) and Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ (10), in which the name of Hermanubis is joined to that of other gods in the characteristic pattern of polytheophoric names. It is misleading to analyze these names as triple theophoric names, for they imply the juxtaposition of only two gods, Hermanubis and Ammon in one, and Hermanubis and Heracles in the other.[15] In this respect, they are not exceptions to the rule that polytheophoric names combine no more than two deities.

The name Hermanubis is often modified with different suffixes to distinguish it from other polytheophoric names, which typically combine two deity names without modification. Personal names like Hermaonbammon and Heraklermanubis only pair Hermanubis with one other deity, therefore they are not considered triple theophoric names.

conversation.content: summarise this: The near majority of the names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri of the second and third centuries AD. Possibly the earliest example is on an ostracon dated to AD 94 (1), but the name there is abbreviated and Ἑρμανο(υβίου) is Wilcken's resolution.[16] Otherwise, the next attestations are from the second quarter of the second century. There are overall eight instances from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. One instance is from an inscription dated broadly to the "imperial period." The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century. What is notable about this chronological distribution is that it corresponds neatly to that of the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known conventionally as "Hermanubis." For example, the great number of Alexandrian coins that show a representation of this type on the reverse range from the reign of Trajan (or possibly as early as Domitian) to the Tetrarchic period. Likewise, the statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs of this god have all been assigned to the second or third century AD.[17]

conversation.content: summarise this: Geographically, names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but it is important to separate, where possible, the provenance of the papyrus from that of the individuals named therein. When this is done, most of the individuals bearing Hermanubis names for whom we can establish an origin turn out to be Alexandrian or Cynopolite (three instances each). This concentration again coincides with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. Thus, in the precinct of the Alexandrian Serapeum an inscription of uncertain date was found (SB I 3482) dedicated to "Hermanubis, great god, who listens to prayers and grants favours" (Ἑρμανούβιδι θεῶι μεγάλωι | ἐπηκόωι καὶ εὐχαρίϲτωι).[18] Not far from this dedication a statuette of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" was discovered.[19] It is in a suburb of Alexandria, in the sanctuary of Ras el-Soda, that the most famous statue of "Hermanubis" was found (LIMC n. 14). One of the Alexandrian coins representing the god shows him standing inside a temple (LIMC nos. 5a, b), which suggests the existence of such an edifice in the city, probably in the Serapeum precinct given the provenance of the just-mentioned dedication and statuette from there and the frequent iconographical associations between "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in Alexandrian coins.[20] Alexandria, then, clearly emerges as the cult center and probably the birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, which is consonant with the three Alexandrians bearing his name (5, 6, 9).[21] For the Cynopolite nome, the chief centre of the Egyptian god Anubis, the onomastic evidence is more suggestive than the archaeological and the iconographical. Among the three individuals with a name based on Hermanubis (11, 15, 16), there stands out the father of an underage priest of "Anubis, Leto and associated gods" in the Cynopolite village of Laura (15). Since priesthood was usually hereditary, the father Hermanubis was probably himself a priest of these gods. This onomastic connection of Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome also has an echo in the iconography: one or two Alexandrian coins personify the Cynopolite nome with a representation of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" on their reverse (LIMC nos. 3, 22).

The name Hermanubis is found in various locations in Egypt, but most of the individuals with this name are from Alexandria or Cynopolite. Alexandria is the likely birthplace and cult center of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, with evidence including inscriptions, a statuette, and a coin featuring the god in a temple. In the Cynopolite nome, the evidence is more suggestive, with only one individual named Hermanubis being the father of a young priest of Anubis and associated gods. The iconography of some Alexandrian coins also associates Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome.

conversation.content: summarise this: Notes See Benaissa 2009. Although it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in the earlier period. The most obvious is the god Ἑρμαφρόδιτοϲ (see Ajootian 1990), attested from the fourth century BC onwards, but his name implies the paradoxical union of two different gods (Hermes and Aphrodite) rather than an assimilation in the manner of Hermanubis. A more apt parallel is provided by Ζηνοποϲειδῶν, an epiclesis of the Carian god Zeus Osogoa, who received the additional determination "Poseidon" as a result of his representation with features such as the trident (see Blümel 1987, 128). In Egyptian religion, the tendency to unite the names of two gods was long established and is well known (cf. Leclant 1975). A comparable form to Hermanubis from the Roman period is Ἡλιοϲέραπιϲ, which is not attested as a personal name (pace Hopfner 1946, 45). Schwartz 1947 also postulates a syncretic funerary god Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, but this is based purely on the iconographical evidence of some seals, without any support from textual sources (the personal name Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, two instances of which have emerged since Schwartz's thesis, could be simply an example of a polytheophoric name and need not imply the recognition of an actual god of that name). The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are collected by Grenier 1977, 53–59, 95–98. Bernand, Inscriptions métriques n. 73 (Abydos; I–II) = GVI 1090, should also be added, as the Κυλλήνιοϲ Ἑρμῆϲ (9) leading the deceased to serve Osiris of Abydos is implicitly conflated with Anubis (see Dunand 1975, 158). Kákosy 1990, 145 points to some pre-Ptolemaic Egyptian statuettes, in which the feet or teeth of Thoth are modeled as jackal heads, as evidence that the later rapprochement of Anubis and Hermes was based on the earlier assimilation of Thoth to Anubis; but although Thoth and Anubis were closely associated in funerary contexts, I am not persuaded that these statuettes "wollten sicher den synkretischen Gott Thoth-Anubis darstellen" or that they are relevant to the question of the origin of the Graeco-Roman Hermanubis. See Leclant 1981, 871, and the references in Grenier 1977, 137–138. In the amulet published in Bonner 1950, n. 36 (Plate II) = LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 19, Anubis is described as holding in his right hand "a tall scepter resembling a Roman military standard, with palm leaves at top, and two garlands, the lower with ties" (Bonner 1950, 259). But this looks to me like a version of the kerykeion-cum-palm known from a number of coins of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis; see Grenier 1990, 265, and cf. the coins under 8(a). Whether the appellation "Hermanubis" was given to the canine-headed Anubis with Hermetic features is uncertain; Apuleius, Met. XI 11, refers to the god attolens canis cernices arduas and laena caduceum gerens simply as "Anubis." LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 13, found in Carthage or Cherchel, is the only representation for which an Alexandrian origin has been postulated, but on no firm basis (see Picard 1956, 176–179, who assigns to it an Alexandrian provenance and a date in the third century BC on the basis of the floral decoration). See Grenier 1990. Cf. Leclant 1981, 873. On "direct theonymy" see Parker 2000, 57–8, with further bibliography. For the accentuation Ἑρμάνουβιϲ rather than Ἑρμανοῦβιϲ (Preisigke and some editors), see Clarysse 1997, 180. While the letter was found in the Fayum, the sender is clearly writing from Alexandria; cf. Bagnall and Cribiore 2006, 389–390. For some observations on the marking of gender in Greek personal names, see Davies 2000, 20–21. Cf. Gignac, Grammar, II 55–57; Mayser, Grammatik, I.2 22–23. For masculine names in -ιϲ, -ιδοϲ/-ιοϲ and feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ, see Pape-Benseler, Wörterbuch der griechischen Eigennamen3, xviii-xix. See e.g. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 33–34; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 34–35. See e.g. the "index des suffixes" in Masson 1990, II 632–633 s.v. -ᾶϲ ("suffixe d'hypocoristique et de sobriquet masculin").

This passage discusses the origins and parallels of Hermanubis, a syncretic god combining the Egyptian god Anubis and the Greek god Hermes. It notes that while it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, there were similar examples in earlier periods, including the god Hermaphroditos (combining Hermes and Aphrodite) and the Carian god Zeus Osogoa (combining Zeus and Poseidon). The passage also explores the association of Anubis with Hermes in literary and epigraphic sources, and discusses the possible origins of the name Hermanubis.

conversation.content: summarise this: The divine name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period.[2] Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect (De Is. et Os. 375e), while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as ϲύνθετοϲ, "composite," and μιξέλλην, "half-Greek" (De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18.1–2 Bidez). The name has been restored in a second-century BC dedicatory inscription from Delos (ID 2156.2 [Ἑρ]μανού[βιδι νικ]ηφόρωι), which would be its earliest attestation, but otherwise it appears in three inscriptions of the Roman period, two from Egypt and one from Thessalonike (see below). It is clear that the name is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in a number of literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources.[3] Although Hermes was traditionally equated with the Egyptian Thoth, his function as psychopompos encouraged his association with Anubis given the latter's comparable funerary role in Egyptian religion as embalmer and guardian of the dead and as leader of the deceased to the tribunal of Osiris. This assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, such as the distinctive staff known as the kerykeion or winged sandals.[4] As far as I know, none of these representations whose provenance is known was found in Egypt, though this may be due to mere chance.[5] But in Roman Alexandria there emerges a new iconographical type, well represented in coins and sculpture, in which a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis, in addition to wearing the calathos headdress.[6] It is this type that art historians have traditionally labeled "Hermanubis." In making this identification, they have been encouraged by Porphyry's statement about the god's "composite" and "half-Hellenic" character. However, it is important to stress that the reference to the fully anthropomorphic type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and that not a single of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.[7] I will return to this question at the end of the paper in light of the onomastic evidence.

The name "Hermanubis" is known from a few sources, mostly from the Roman period, and is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes. This assimilation resulted in representations of Anubis with attributes of Hermes, and in Roman Alexandria a new iconographical type emerged where a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes. It is important to note that the reference to this type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and not a single representation of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.

conversation.content: summarise this: The ending -άμμων was attached to the names of most deities that appear in theophoric names (see Dunand 1963), so that its union with Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is unlikely to have a specific significance. One may adduce some numismatic representations in which "Hermanubis" is shown with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon; see LIMC V s.v. Hermanubis nos. 10a, b. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more intriguing and difficult to account for. If the papyrus is from the Heracleopolite nome as the ed. princ. suggests with a question mark (no internal evidence confirms this), the name may simply juxtapose the chief god of the nome (Heracles = Egyptian Harsenuphis) with Hermanubis, without necessarily implying an affinity between the two. For what it is worth, a coin from the reign of Antoninus Pius (Milne, Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins 1678 [Plate II]) shows jugate busts of Heracles and "Hermanubis." For a representation of the dog-headed Anubis with a club, see LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 35. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ does not actually occur in Egyptian documents, though Ἀνούβιοϲ is occasionally attested. The Macedonian inscription discussed below (22) is the only instance of the form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ. See Grenier 1990. On this inscription see Fraser 1972, II 413–414 n. 576. For another inscription from Egypt mentioning Hermanubis, see SB I 238. Fraser 1972, I 269. It is not clear to me to which of the statuettes in LIMC this corresponds (n. 21?). On the associations of "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in iconography, see Grenier 1990, 268. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis attested in 13 (and possibly 14) may also originate from Alexandria. Cf. Plut., De Is. et Os. 375e: Ἄνουβιϲ ... ὅτε καὶ Ἑρμάνουβιϲ ὀνομάζεται, τὸ μὲν ὡϲ τοῖϲ ἄνω τὸ δ᾿ ὡϲ τοῖϲ κάτω προϲήκων. Blumell, ZPE 165 (2008) 186–190. I have not been able to consult D. Stefanovic, "The Iconography of Hermanubis," in H. Györy (ed.), Aegyptus et Pannonia III. Representations of "Hermanubis" on coins and in art often show a fusion of aspects of both Hermes and Anubis. The form "Ἑρμανούβιοϲ" is not found in Egyptian documents, only in a Macedonian inscription. conversation.content: summarise this: The near majority of the names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri of the second and third centuries AD. Possibly the earliest example is on an ostracon dated to AD 94 (1), but the name there is abbreviated and Ἑρμανο(υβίου) is Wilcken's resolution.[16] Otherwise, the next attestations are from the second quarter of the second century. There are overall eight instances from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. One instance is from an inscription dated broadly to the "imperial period." The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century. What is notable about this chronological distribution is that it corresponds neatly to that of the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known conventionally as "Hermanubis." For example, the great number of Alexandrian coins that show a representation of this type on the reverse range from the reign of Trajan (or possibly as early as Domitian) to the Tetrarchic period. Likewise, the statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs of this god have all been assigned to the second or third century AD.[17]

conversation.content: summarise this: The personal name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ and related forms are usually subsumed under the category of "polytheophoric" names characteristic of Roman Egypt. These are names that combine the names of two deities, such as Ἡρακλαπόλλων or Ἑρμαντίνοοϲ. They are attested solely in the Roman period, especially between the second and the fourth centuries, and were predominantly popular among males of the middle and upper classes in certain metropoleis like Hermopolis.[1] The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, however, though formally combining two divine names, is somewhat special: unlike other polytheophoric names, it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested in Roman Egypt. In other words, it is the name of the god himself that is a "polytheophoric" formation, and this has some consequences on how the personal names based on this deity are formed. Before discussing these names, it is appropriate first to give a brief summary of our state of knowledge about Hermanubis. After reviewing the name forms based on this deity, the onomastic evidence will be related and compared to his iconographical and documentary attestations.

conversation.content: summarise this: Geographically, names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but it is important to separate, where possible, the provenance of the papyrus from that of the individuals named therein. When this is done, most of the individuals bearing Hermanubis names for whom we can establish an origin turn out to be Alexandrian or Cynopolite (three instances each). This concentration again coincides with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. Thus, in the precinct of the Alexandrian Serapeum an inscription of uncertain date was found (SB I 3482) dedicated to "Hermanubis, great god, who listens to prayers and grants favours" (Ἑρμανούβιδι θεῶι μεγάλωι | ἐπηκόωι καὶ εὐχαρίϲτωι).[18] Not far from this dedication a statuette of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" was discovered.[19] It is in a suburb of Alexandria, in the sanctuary of Ras el-Soda, that the most famous statue of "Hermanubis" was found (LIMC n. 14). One of the Alexandrian coins representing the god shows him standing inside a temple (LIMC nos. 5a, b), which suggests the existence of such an edifice in the city, probably in the Serapeum precinct given the provenance of the just-mentioned dedication and statuette from there and the frequent iconographical associations between "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in Alexandrian coins.[20] Alexandria, then, clearly emerges as the cult center and probably the birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, which is consonant with the three Alexandrians bearing his name (5, 6, 9).[21] For the Cynopolite nome, the chief centre of the Egyptian god Anubis, the onomastic evidence is more suggestive than the archaeological and the iconographical. Among the three individuals with a name based on Hermanubis (11, 15, 16), there stands out the father of an underage priest of "Anubis, Leto and associated gods" in the Cynopolite village of Laura (15). Since priesthood was usually hereditary, the father Hermanubis was probably himself a priest of these gods. This onomastic connection of Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome also has an echo in the iconography: one or two Alexandrian coins personify the Cynopolite nome with a representation of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" on their reverse (LIMC nos. 3, 22).

Hermanubis names have been found in various parts of Egypt, but most individuals with the name originated from Alexandria or the Cynopolite nome. Archaeological evidence also points to Alexandria as the cult center and likely birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis. In the Cynopolite nome, the onomastic evidence suggests a connection between Hermanubis and the god Anubis, and this is echoed in some Alexandrian coin iconography.

conversation.content: summarise this: The ending -άμμων was attached to the names of most deities that appear in theophoric names (see Dunand 1963), so that its union with Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is unlikely to have a specific significance. One may adduce some numismatic representations in which "Hermanubis" is shown with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon; see LIMC V s.v. Hermanubis nos. 10a, b. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more intriguing and difficult to account for. If the papyrus is from the Heracleopolite nome as the ed. princ. suggests with a question mark (no internal evidence confirms this), the name may simply juxtapose the chief god of the nome (Heracles = Egyptian Harsenuphis) with Hermanubis, without necessarily implying an affinity between the two. For what it is worth, a coin from the reign of Antoninus Pius (Milne, Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins 1678 [Plate II]) shows jugate busts of Heracles and "Hermanubis." For a representation of the dog-headed Anubis with a club, see LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 35. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ does not actually occur in Egyptian documents, though Ἀνούβιοϲ is occasionally attested. The Macedonian inscription discussed below (22) is the only instance of the form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ. See Grenier 1990. On this inscription see Fraser 1972, II 413–414 n. 576. For another inscription from Egypt mentioning Hermanubis, see SB I 238. Fraser 1972, I 269. It is not clear to me to which of the statuettes in LIMC this corresponds (n. 21?). On the associations of "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in iconography, see Grenier 1990, 268. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis attested in 13 (and possibly 14) may also originate from Alexandria. Cf. Plut., De Is. et Os. 375e: Ἄνουβιϲ ... ὅτε καὶ Ἑρμάνουβιϲ ὀνομάζεται, τὸ μὲν ὡϲ τοῖϲ ἄνω τὸ δ᾿ ὡϲ τοῖϲ κάτω προϲήκων. Addendum, January 2010: The female name Ἑρμανουβίαινα (referring to an ἀϲτή, i.e. a citizen of Alexandria or one of the three Greek cities of Egypt) is now attested in P.Mich. inv. 1960.3 (17 March 291), published by L.H. Blumell, ZPE 165 (2008) 186–190. I have not been able to consult D. Stefanovic, "The Iconography of Hermanubis," in H. Györy (ed.), Aegyptus et Pannonia III. Acta Symposii anno 2004 (Budapest 2006) 271–276. For a recent text and translation of this work, see Lukinovich and Martingay 1997. Ch. Jungck's edition with commentary (Diss. Basel 1974) was not available to me.

The ending -άμμων was commonly added to the names of deities in theophoric names, so the combination of Ἑρμάνουβιϲ may not be significant. Some numismatic representations of "Hermanubis" show him with attributes of both Hermes and Ammon. The origin of the name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is unclear, but it could be a juxtaposition of the chief god of a nome with Hermanubis. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ is not found in Egyptian documents, but is attested in a Macedonian inscription. There is debate around the associations between Hermanubis and Sarapis in iconography, and an acting epistrategus Hermanubis is mentioned in Plutarch's De Is. et Os. The name Ἑρμανουβίαινα has also been found in a papyrus. Some related works were not available to the author.

conversation.content: summarise this: The near majority of the names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri of the second and third centuries AD. Possibly the earliest example is on an ostracon dated to AD 94 (1), but the name there is abbreviated and Ἑρμανο(υβίου) is Wilcken's resolution.[16] Otherwise, the next attestations are from the second quarter of the second century. There are overall eight instances from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. One instance is from an inscription dated broadly to the "imperial period." The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century. What is notable about this chronological distribution is that it corresponds neatly to that of the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known conventionally as "Hermanubis." For example, the great number of Alexandrian coins that show a representation of this type on the reverse range from the reign of Trajan (or possibly as early as Domitian) to the Tetrarchic period. Likewise, the statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs of this god have all been assigned to the second or third century AD.[17]

The majority of names based on Hermanubis are found in papyri from the second and third centuries AD, with the earliest known example being from AD 94. There are eight instances from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth, with one instance from an undated inscription from the "imperial period." This chronological distribution mirrors that of the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known as "Hermanubis," with coins from the reign of Trajan to the Tetrarchic period and statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs from the second or third century AD. The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century.

conversation.content: summarise this: 	There are three forms of the personal name based on Hermanubis in papyri and inscriptions from Egypt, in addition to two "proper" polytheophoric names. (In four instances [1, 5, 17, 21] the ending of the name is abbreviated or not preserved.) The form Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, attested six times (2, 9, 11, 13, 14, 15), simply replicates the god's name without further ado, through the phenomenon of "direct theonymy" (the giving to humans of unaltered divine names) that became widespread in the Roman period.[8] In an odd instance (9) the form Ἑρμανουβιϲ in the nominative is borne by a woman, an Alexandrian nurse (ἡ τροφόϲ).[9] It is highly unusual for female theophoric names to be unmarked for gender in this way.[10] I suspect that because the element -ανουβιϲ in Ἑρμάνουβιϲ was often declined with a dental declension in -ιδ-, it might have been conflated with the similar declension of Greek feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ.[11] If this is correct, it may be preferable to read the nurse's name as an oxytone (Ἑρμανουβίϲ). There are two further forms based on the god Hermanubis: Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (six instances: 3, 4, 7, 8, 12, 20) and Ἑρμανουβίων (four instances: 3, 6, 18, 19). -ᾶϲ and -ίων were, in fact, the commonest Greek suffixes for personal names based on the Egyptian god Ἄνουβιϲ.[12] It is interesting that in a business letter (3) the two forms Ἑρμανουβίων (l.38) and Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (l.41) are used interchangeably to designate the same individual. In this case, Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ is probably a hypocoristic of Ἑρμανουβίων, since the suffix -ᾶϲ often served this purpose.[13]

The personal name based on the god Hermanubis can take three forms in papyri and inscriptions from Egypt, with two additional polytheophoric names. The form Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, attested six times, simply replicates the god's name. In an unusual instance, a woman bears the nominative form. Two further forms based on the god are Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ and Ἑρμανουβίων. These suffixes were common for personal names based on the Egyptian god Ἄνουβιϲ. In one case, the two forms were used interchangeably to designate the same individual, with one likely being a hypocoristic of the other.

The form Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, attested six times (2, 9, 11, 13, 14, 15), simply replicates the god's name without further ado, through the phenomenon of "direct theonymy" (the giving to humans of unaltered divine names) that became widespread in the Roman period.[8] In an odd instance (9) the form Ἑρμανουβιϲ in the nominative is borne by a woman, an Alexandrian nurse (ἡ τροφόϲ).[9] It is highly unusual for female theophoric names to be unmarked for gender in this way.[10] I suspect that because the element -ανουβιϲ in Ἑρμάνουβιϲ was often declined with a dental declension in -ιδ-, it might have been conflated with the similar declension of Greek feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ.[11] If this is correct, it may be preferable to read the nurse's name as an oxytone (Ἑρμανουβίϲ). There are two further forms based on the god Hermanubis: Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (six instances: 3, 4, 7, 8, 12, 20) and Ἑρμανουβίων (four instances: 3, 6, 18, 19). -ᾶϲ and -ίων were, in fact, the commonest Greek suffixes for personal names based on the Egyptian god Ἄνουβιϲ.[12] It is interesting that in a business letter (3) the two forms Ἑρμανουβίων (l.38) and Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (l.41) are used interchangeably to designate the same individual. In this case, Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ is probably a hypocoristic of Ἑρμανουβίων, since the suffix -ᾶϲ often served this purpose.[13]

There are multiple forms of personal names based on the deity Hermanubis, including Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ, and Ἑρμανουβίων. The first form directly replicates the god's name and is found in six instances, including one instance where it is used as a female name. The use of -ᾶϲ and -ίων as suffixes in the other forms is common in Greek names based on the Egyptian god Ἄνουβιϲ. These forms are used interchangeably in some instances, with -ᾶϲ possibly serving as a hypocoristic of -ίων.

Hermanubis
Hermanubis is a God who combines aspects of the Hellenic deity Hermes with Kemetic deity Anubis. Hermes and Anubis’s similar responsibilities (both being conductor of the soul, or psychopomps, who lead souls to the afterlife) led to the discovery of Hermanubis, who acted as an assimilation of Anubis into the Hellenic pantheon. Hermanubis represents the Egyptian priesthood, engaged in the investigation of truth. He is the son of the deities Isis and Serapis. The worship of Hermanubis was popular during the Roman era of Egypt.
Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect, while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as “σύνθετος,” meaning “composite” and “μιξέλλην,” meaning “half-Greek.”
Iconography
Hermanubis is typically depicted as having a human body and jackal head, with the sacred caduceus. Sometimes a solar disk is depicted on His head. At times He is also depicted wearing a soldiers armour, but more common are priestly garbs.
Bibliography
Porphyry, De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18. 1–2 Bidez

HELLENIC FAITH Hellenic Faith is a website dedicated to Julian Hellenism, a reformed denomination of Hellenism, the polytheistic religion of the Graeco-Roman world, influenced by the teachings and writings of Julian the Philosopher (r. 361-363 ACE) and the divine Iamblichus (c. 245-325 ACE). It is a Orphic-Platonic tradition, derived from the teachings of Orpheus through the Platonic school, and solar-based, centered around the worship of the omnipotent creator God, King Zeus-Helios.

Hermanubis
Hermanubis is a God who combines aspects of the Hellenic deity Hermes with Kemetic deity Anubis. Hermes and Anubis’s similar responsibilities (both being conductor of the soul, or psychopomps, who lead souls to the afterlife) led to the discovery of Hermanubis, who acted as an assimilation of Anubis into the Hellenic pantheon. Hermanubis represents the Egyptian priesthood, engaged in the investigation of truth. He is the son of the deities Isis and Serapis. The worship of Hermanubis was popular during the Roman era of Egypt.
Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect, while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as “σύνθετος,” meaning “composite” and “μιξέλλην,” meaning “half-Greek.”
Iconography
Hermanubis is typically depicted as having a human body and jackal head, with the sacred caduceus. Sometimes a solar disk is depicted on His head. At times He is also depicted wearing a soldiers armour, but more common are priestly garbs.
Bibliography
Porphyry, De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18. 1–2 Bidez

HELLENIC FAITH Hellenic Faith is a website dedicated to Julian Hellenism, a reformed denomination of Hellenism, the polytheistic religion of the Graeco-Roman world, influenced by the teachings and writings of Julian the Philosopher (r. 361-363 ACE) and the divine Iamblichus (c. 245-325 ACE). It is a Orphic-Platonic tradition, derived from the teachings of Orpheus through the Platonic school, and solar-based, centered around the worship of the omnipotent creator God, King Zeus-Helios.

Download Free PDFDownload Free PDFForest Regeneration of The Bateke Plateau Savannahs From Acacia Auriculformis Plantations in The Democratic Republic of The Congo.Forest Regeneration of The Bateke Plateau Savannahs From Acacia Auriculformis Plantations in The Democratic Republic of The Congo.Forest Regeneration of The Bateke Plateau Savannahs From Acacia Auriculformis Plantations in The Democratic Republic of The Congo.Forest Regeneration of The Bateke Plateau Savannahs From Acacia Auriculformis Plantations in The Democratic Republic of The Congo.Forest Regeneration of The Bateke Plateau Savannahs From Acacia Auriculformis Plantations in The Democratic Republic of The Congo.IJERD JOURNALABSTRACT: Agroforestry applied on the set of Bateke, DRC was the subject of a scientific analysis based on natural forest regeneration inventories in the undergrowth A. auriculiformis and A.mangium, a time sequence of six different ages (3, 4, 7, 9, 10 and 29years). It aims to evaluate, analyze and measure the impact of agroforestry systems (SAFTS) on natural forest regeneration after reforestation plantations A. auriculiformis, to A. mangium and conservation of biodiversity on the plateau of Bateke. Multivariate analysis of the generalized linear model procedure (GLM) performed on the collected database, revealed a significant effect of the species on the site, the age of plantations, the DBH (cm), the total height of shaft (m) and basal area (m2 / ha). The results obtained as the establishment of plantations present evolving stages of secondary forest succession which also appear on the plantations in abandoned plantations A. auriculiformis and A.mangium. A forest ecosystem is recovering quite quickly on the perimeter plantings A. auriculiformis and A. mangium in place of the former savannah ecosystem characteristic’ plateau Bateke.See Full PDFDownload PDFSee Full PDFDownload PDFRelated PapersBois et Forêts des tropiquesLes Plans Simples de Gestion destinés à la production de bois-énergie en périphérie de Kinshasa : la participation et la restauration à l’épreuve du foncier2019 • Cédric VermeulenIn the Democratic Republic of Congo, slashand-burn agriculture and fuelwood production are the main income-generating activities for peri-urban populations. However, these activities are also primary causes of deforestation in a 200 km radius around Kinshasa and around the country’s other large cities. Aiming to improve the management of peri-urban areas and ensure sustainable fuelwood supplies for Kinshasa, the EU Makala project, using a participatory method, co-developed a series of Simple Management Plans for local areas and fuelwood production with twelve Batéké Plateau and Kongo-Central communities. To back up the plans, technical management methods (agroforestry plantations using Acacia auriculiformis and local species, assisted natural regeneration) were proposed and tested with farmers in these communities, who also produce fuelwood. After 18 months of autonomous implementation of the Simple Management Plans, the level of appropriation was assessed via the Principles, Criteria, Indicators and Verifiers method. This assessment showed a higher level of appropriation of the Simple Management Plans and technical management methods promoted by the EU Makala Project in Kongo-Central, where virtually no forest is left, than on the Batéké Plateau, where there are still some remnants of gallery forest. The assessment also showed that in both zones, appropriation was lower for collective activities than individual activities, where the division of tasks and the distribution of benefits were clearer. However, notable differences in appropriation by individuals appeared according to their land tenure status. The small size of available land areas and access to land are the main factors that limit appropriation of technical agroforestry management methods.Download Free PDFView PDFMondes en développementAgroforesterie et déforestation en République démocratique du Congo. DJOTAN, GCR GbaguidiThe harvest of the seeds of Acacia auriculiformis becomes very difficult when the tree gets older. This study has assessed the viability, and the germination performance of the species’ seeds eventually conserved in the soil. For this purpose, an experiment was carried out over a period of seven weeks to count the number of seedlings emerging from the composite soil samples collected in an old plantation of Acacia auriculiformis in South Benin. Samples were randomly collected over a horizontally stratified scale (provenance), but systematically collected over a vertically stratified scale (depth). Relief Fragment Depicting Hermanubis Thumbnail
Relief Fragment Depicting Hermanubis
Roman
(Sculptor)
1st-2nd century CE (Roman Imperial)
marble (Roman Empire )
This relief fragment depicts Hermanubis, a deity that combined the elements of Egyptian Anubis (including the head of a jackal) with those of Graeco-Roman Hermes/Mercury. Although the jackal head is almost completely obliterated, traces of a long, pointed ear are visible on the left side of the stone, while the snout is partially preserved below the break. His garment is secured with a circular fibula over his left shoulder, leaving his right arm and part of his chest exposed. In his proper right hand, he grips the handle of an object, possibly a sistrum based on other Roman-period depictions of the god. He may have held a caduceus or a palm frond in his now-missing left arm.
The piece is cut off and worked rough at the right side and in a diagonal line at the top. There are two dowel holes in the top, and one in the side. There is clamp cutting at the top, and mortar in the drapery.
Provenance
Provenance (from the French provenir, 'to come from/forth') is the chronology of the ownership, custody, or location of a historical object.
Don Marcello Massarenti Collection, Rome, by 1894, [mode of acquisition unknown] [marble no. 62]; Henry Walters, Baltimore, 1902, by purchase; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.

The Onomastic Evidence for the God Hermanubis
Amin Benaissa
Skip other details (including permanent urls, DOI, citation information)
Permalink: http://hdl.handle.net/2027/spo.7523866.0025.116
The work is protected by copyright, and can be linked to without permission. However, any subsequent distribution (in print or electronically) requires permission to be granted. For more information, contact mpub-help@umich.edu.
For more information, read Michigan Publishing's access and usage policy.
The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is a “polytheophoric” name that combines two deity names, but unlike most, it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested in Roman Egypt. The personal names based on this deity are formed differently due to this uniqueness. This article provides a summary of the knowledge about Hermanubis, including onomastic evidence compared to his iconographical and documentary attestations.
The name “Hermanubis” is known from a few sources, mostly from the Roman period, and is believed to be the result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes. This resulted in representations of Anubis with attributes of Hermes. In Roman Alexandria, a new iconographical type emerged featuring a fully anthropomorphic young god flanked by a dog and holding the same attributes as Anubis, which art historians have labeled “Hermanubis.” However, this identification is only a hypothetical convention, and there is no inscription identifying the representations as such.
There are various forms of the personal name based on Hermanubis in Egyptian papyri and inscriptions, including some polytheophoric names. The form “Hermanubis” is replicated without alteration in six instances, while other forms include “Hermanoubas” and “Hermanoubiōn.” It is unusual for a female theophoric name to be unmarked for gender, but a nurse’s name in the nominative case is an exception. The suffixes “-ᾶϲ” and “-ίων” are commonly used in personal names based on the Egyptian god Anubis, and in some cases, two forms of the Hermanubis name are used interchangeably to designate the same individual. The suffix “-ᾶϲ” often serves as a hypocoristic.
The name variations of Hermanubis distinguish it from other polytheistic names by modifying the suffix. Personal names that include Hermanubis and other gods are common, but they do not imply triple theophoric names as they only join two gods together. Polytheistic names typically only combine two deities.
Most names based on Hermanubis are found in papyri from the second and third centuries AD, with the earliest example possibly dating to AD 94. There are a total of eight instances from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth, with one instance being from an inscription dated broadly to the “imperial period.” The distribution of the evidence corresponds neatly to the chronological distribution of iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known as “Hermanubis,” with representations ranging from the reign of Trajan to the Tetrarchic period. The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century.
Hermanubis names have been found in various parts of Egypt, but most individuals with the name originated from Alexandria or the Cynopolite nome. Archaeological evidence also points to Alexandria as the cult center and likely birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis. In the Cynopolite nome, the onomastic evidence suggests a connection between Hermanubis and the god Anubis, and this is echoed in some Alexandrian coin iconography.
This article discusses an onomastic survey of names based on the god Hermanubis in Roman Egypt. The survey found that Hermanubis names are unique from other polytheophoric names as they refer to a specific and independently attested god, and they also show connections to the traditional Anubis. The overlap between the onomastic evidence and representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god known as “Hermanubis” supports the designation of the latter as such. Therefore, it may not be necessary to separate traditional funerary Anubis from a more “universalizing” Hermanubis.
The name Hermanubis is found once outside Egypt in a Macedonian inscription during the imperial period, with a slightly different spelling. This may be related to the Hermanubis cult, which was also found in Thessalonike with a dedication from the third century. A statue of the god was also found in the Sarapeum of Carthage. These findings suggest that the Hermanubis cult was popular outside of Egypt during the Roman period.
This is Appendix 1, which is a list of names related to Hermanubis. It includes the name bearer’s province, the date of the document, and other data. The list features three names: Ἑρμανο(), Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, and Ἑρμανουβίων. The provinces associated with the names are Thebes, Denderah, and Stras respectively.

This appendix provides two literary examples of the name Hermanubis, in addition to a survey of its occurrence in ancient inscriptions. The first is a passage from Gregory of Nazianzus’ autobiography, where the name appears in relation to Maximus the Cynic’s failed attempt to become bishop of Constantinople in 380. Gregory mentions Egyptian sailors who were instructed by Peter, bishop of Alexandria, to spy on him and aid Maximus, whom he names and criticizes.
